name: Breathing Exercises
description: Breathwork for calm, focus and energy

exercises.name: Box Breathing
exercises.description: Navy SEAL technique for calm under pressure — 4-4-4-4 pattern
instructions: Sit comfortably with feet flat on the floor
Close your eyes or soften your gaze
Exhale completely to empty your lungs
INHALE slowly through your nose for 4 counts
HOLD your breath for 4 counts
EXHALE slowly through your mouth for 4 counts
HOLD empty for 4 counts
Repeat for 4-8 cycles
benefits: Lowers heart rate and blood pressure

exercises.name: 4-7-8 Breathing
exercises.description: Dr. Andrew Weil's relaxing breath — natural tranquiliser for the nervous system
instructions: Sit or lie in a comfortable position
Place tongue tip behind your upper front teeth
Keep tongue there throughout the exercise
Exhale completely through your mouth with a whoosh
INHALE quietly through your nose for 4 counts
HOLD your breath for 7 counts
EXHALE completely through mouth for 8 counts (whoosh)
Repeat for 4 cycles (work up to 8 over time)

modifications.easier: Reduce hold time, maintain the ratio

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.description: Deep belly breathing that maximises oxygen intake and calms the mind
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, or sit comfortably
Place one hand on your chest, one on your belly
Breathe in slowly through your nose
Feel your BELLY rise while chest stays still
Your lower hand should rise, upper hand stays quiet
Exhale slowly through pursed lips
Feel your belly fall as you empty your lungs
Continue for 5-10 minutes

modifications.easier: Just focus on belly rising, don't worry about chest
modifications.harder: Add a book on your belly for feedback

exercises.name: Physiological Sigh
exercises.description: Stanford neuroscience technique — fastest way to calm down in real-time
instructions: This is the fastest way to reduce stress in the moment
Take a deep inhale through your nose
At the top, take a SECOND short inhale (double inhale)
This reinflates the collapsed air sacs in your lungs
Then exhale very slowly through your mouth
The exhale should be longer than the inhales combined
One cycle is often enough to feel calmer
Repeat 2-3 times if needed

exercises.name: Alternate Nostril Breathing
exercises.description: Yogic breathing that balances left and right brain hemispheres
instructions: Sit comfortably with spine tall
Rest left hand on your knee
Bring right hand to your face
Use thumb to close right nostril
INHALE through left nostril for 4 counts
Close left nostril with ring finger, release thumb
EXHALE through right nostril for 4 counts
INHALE through right nostril for 4 counts
Close right nostril, release left
EXHALE through left nostril for 4 counts
This is one complete cycle — repeat 5-10 times

exercises.name: Energising Breath
exercises.description: Quick, rhythmic breathing to increase alertness and energy
instructions: Sit tall with shoulders relaxed
Take a few normal breaths to settle
Begin quick, rhythmic breaths through your nose
Both inhale and exhale should be short and equal
Keep your mouth closed
Pump your belly with each exhale
Start with 15-20 breaths per round
Take a break and breathe normally between rounds
Do 2-3 rounds total

modifications.harder: More breaths per round, add breath holds

exercises.name: Resonance Breathing
exercises.description: 5.5 breaths per minute — the optimal rate for heart rate variability
instructions: Sit or lie in a comfortable position
Set a timer for 5 minutes to start
Breathe in through your nose for about 5.5 seconds
Breathe out through your nose for about 5.5 seconds
No pause between breaths — continuous flow
This equals about 5.5 breaths per minute
Focus on the smoothness of your breath
Let your belly expand naturally on inhale

modifications.easier: Start with 4-second inhale/exhale and work up
